185109.description: The Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers Age of Ultron – Collector's Box has everything 1 player needs to get started playing Dice Masters! Each Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers Age of Ultron –Collector's Box contains: 20 custom dice, 1 felt dice bag, 10 Basic Action Cards, 4 Indicator Cards, 1 Full Art Promo Card, 4 Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers Age of Ultron Foil Packs, and 2 dice storage trays that hold over 300 dice.
185109.name: Marvel Dice Masters: Age of Ultron – Collector's Box

185110.name: Hecate
185110.description:
From publisher blurb:

"I swear by the black pits of Tartarus that I WILL release the Titans, I WILL claim the throne of Olympus, and I WILL. DEFEAT. JUPITER!"

Hecate is a powerful titan who was raised as the goddess of magic, and who believes she has been wronged at the hands of her adopted father Zeus and passed over in favor of the young goddess Jupiter. She has suffered defeat at Jupiter's hands… but Hecate always has a plan to turn defeat into victory! Iconic Legends. Because sometimes you a need a character everyone knows, even if they're meeting them for the first time.

185111.name: The Overlords
185111.description:
From publisher blurb:

The villainous Overlords are dangerous super-criminals on their own, but their ability to commit crime and unleash destruction multiplies when they work together! Even worse, the missions that Blackguard (PL 9), Disruptor (PL 7), Fallout (PL 8), Feedback (PL 9), and Vortex (PL 10) are sent on are secretly part of Hauptman Klaue's greater schemes for world domination!

185112.name: A Council of Genies
185112.description:
From publisher blurb:

You've Been Called Before the Council!

Genies are creatures of ancient extraplanar cultures able to call upon vast innate magics, command the elements, and draw upon the wisdom of the ages. They are also often capricious, driven, and unwilling to consider the concerns of lesser beings. They are, in short, perfect foils for a band of overconfident adventurers! You can never have too many of such magnificent GM tools, so Monster Menagerie: Council of Genies adds to the scant handful of genies a GM might find useful Within its pages you'll find:

Genies with ties to non-elemental planes, such as the positive plane, negative plane, and plane of shadow.
Genius with ties to multiple planes or environmental conditions, such as air and cold, or earth and fire.
Genies native to the Material plane … and no love of its other inhabitants.
Genies driven by greed, sadism, grim pragmatism, or a desperate need to be free spirits – all primed to flesh out a less-colorful side quest, or take center stage in an epic storyline.




So go ahead. Make a wish. If you dare ...

185113.name: Gravaton (ICONS)
185113.description:
From publisher blurb:

Dr. Adrian Lerner was THAT guy. He was the one who walked around the lab as though he was superior to everyone and he loved pointing it out. That changed the day a lab accident produced wonderful powers to control gravity. Unfortunately, having powers reinforced his belief that he was superior. He will now prove it to the world unless your heroes can stop him.

185115.name: Earning Your Stripes
185115.description:
From publisher blurb:

To know is the call, but it's far from all. A way of speaking is a way of knowing, learn a new language to get the thoughts flowing. Are you curious of the horses of striped fur? Of course it is to the zebra I refer.

New feats, spells, and lore all designed for zebra!

185116.name: Bloody Basic: Sinew & Steel Edition
rpg: Blood & Treasure Fantasy Role Playing Game
185116.description:
From publisher blurb:

Bloody Basic takes the advanced Blood & Treasure Fantasy Role Playing rules and boils them down to the essentials to make gaming easy, fast and fun.

The Sinew & Steel Edition rules remove the magic and supernatural elements from the game, making it a game of medieval adventure. It includes rules for creating medieval characters, adventuring, jousting, and besieging and storming castles.

185118.name: FERpg: The Fast and Easy Rpg
rpg: FERpg: The Fast and Easy Rpg
185118.description:
User summary:

The premise of FERpg is to provide a very simple, "single use", rule set for gaming so that experienced gamers can take an occasional break from their normal roleplaying system and have a fun one-off or two-off adventure with another system. To this end, the rules here are exceptionally simple and fast.

One player will be the GameRunner, a sort of narrative expert and tie-breaker (light-weight GM); the remaining players will create characters. Characters have a name and "some quick info" which are narrative tags describing appearance and ability. For the Character's Main Job, a rank of 2d4+2 is assigned. For their Secondary Job, a rank of 1d4+2 is assigned. For anything else, a rank of 1d4 is assigned. All scores summed provide Hit Points. Characters then buy equipment.

For any attempted action that is non-trivial, players roll 1d12 and must roll under their relevant Ability. If the character has no relevant ability they use their lowest score divided by two, rounded up (usually, they will have to roll a 1 to succeed). After every session, players have three chances to improve a Character Ability--1d12 is rolled and if it rolls over the ability then the ability increases by one.

In Combat, initiative is determined by coin flip. Characters again roll under a target, this time their opponents relevant defensing ability (if any). For anything not covered in the rules or for any arguments that may arise, the GameRunner makes a decision which is final.

The rules also include two brief scenarios: Mobhits, a gangster scenario in New York City during the 1920s; and, Gapnack, a comical fantasy scenario with odd flying things.

185119.name: The Wastelanders: 2048
185119.description:
The Wastelanders: 2048 is a lite 4x- (EXplore, EXpand, EXploit and EXterminate) that simulates a Socio-Economic Post-Apocalyptic city using a card draw and hand management system to populate a modular board by laying card tiles called Placements.

The Wastelanders: 2048 is a game exclusively printed by The Game Crafter and was finished May of 2016. A earlier game "The Wastelanders" was scraped and discarded to make way for the redesigned and vastly superior 2048.

Players interact with the city using Wastelanders that are recruited and armed using a card drafting system. Each Wastelander once per turn is allowed one Grid Movement. Each Wastelander represents a single Action Point the player can choose to use on that Wastelanders current placement location.

The list of actions are, Forage, Salvage, Recruit, Assault, and Control. Forage, Salvage, Recruit, and Assault all use Dice Rolls to predict success. Whereas control is Placement specific and is an active or passive bonus earned from Controlling The Area.

The game at its heart is a Player Elimination Game that revolves around a Take That mechanic where player life is represented by Food, and by Wastelanders alive. The game is lost when all Wastelanders have been killed or starved to death the later dealing with major elements of Player Verse Environment.

What is a Socio-Economic Apocalypse? Total social breakdown. Think food riots and fighting in the streets, a world on fire without solution. Major cities collapsing under the weight of anarchy. The Wastelanders is based on a future of food scarcity, a very real Soylent Green is People type of society without any solutions. After, empty husks of cities as the world burns unable to sustain its infrastructure or itself any longer.

Each copy of the game comes with

54 Placement Cards
36 Recruitment Cards
36 Event Cards
96 Item Cards
32 Card Stands of 4 Different Colors
1 D-6
1 D-20

And 20 Ammo Tokens, 38 Famine Tokens, 50 Food Tokens

185120.name: Swansong
185120.description:
From publisher blurb:

Swansong is a story roleplaying game about a rock band’s final tour. Not just any band. But a record-shattering supergroup. For decades the band changed its look, members, and stage show, but their hypnotic music gave meaning and voice to generations and their rallying fans never waivered. Now, age and tedium have reduced the band to a shell of its former self. Bickering, politics, and music industry woes threaten to stop the tour before it even starts.

Protocol is a series of story roleplaying games that thrusts characters together into dramatic situations. Each game uses the same set of rules, with vastly different parameters, start points, characters, and finales. Players take on the roles of directors outside the action and characters inside the action, using the ebb and flow of four different scene-framing styles (vignettes, interrogations, interludes, and ensembles) to tell meaningful stories about characters in crisis.

Each game in the Protocol series is zero-prep for 3 or more players. The game length is exponentially long, so games with more players take more time to complete. The Protocol Series requires a deck of poker cards as well as tokens to track drama points.

185121.description:
Xoliba is a fast-paced, surprising and totally new abstract strategy game. It has no standard starting position. Instead, before each game a new starting position is created by placing game pieces on the board at random. As there are billions of possible starting positions, each game is different from the next. Because the starting position is randomized, it seldom offers equal opportunities for both players and you may well need luck to win. Sometimes you can find yourself much worse off from the very beginning; in such positions all what you can do is to minimize your loss. Do not get discouraged: Xoliba is played in matches and the next game might well be yours.

The objective of the game is to create triangles. The game is won by the player who has the biggest triangle on the board when the game ends. Moves are made by changing places of the player's own piece and a neutral white piece in such a manner that a new triangle is formed. If such a triangle contains player's own or opponent's pieces, they are captured. The game ends when no new triangles can be formed. The winner scores points from enemy pieces that have been captured. The match is won by the player who is the first to reach or exceed 50 points. Of course, it is not obligatory to play up to 50 points. If the players so wish, they can also play shorter or longer matches, for example, up to 35 points.

Equipment

7x7 octagonal board with 45 intersections (corners cut off), points, where horizontal, oblique, and vertical lines cross each other. Game pieces are 57 discs. Each disc has a white side but the colour of the opposite side varies: in 17 discs it is red, in 17 discs it is blue, in 12 it is green and in 11 it is white.
185121.name: Xoliba

185122.name: For Whom the Bell Tolls
185122.description:
From publisher blurb:

For a level 17 party!

In the vast emptiness of the Astral Plane, a bell is ringing.

Ding! Demons are beckoned with its call.

Dong! Angels rise with its chorus.

Ding! Its song spells ruin and woe.

Dong! The fate of worlds hang in the balance!

Somewhere on the Astral Plane, the Bell of Eternity is ringing. This mysterious relic of a forgotten age brings the ruin of whichever world it finishes its song upon. The forces of both angels and demons are vying for its control, and success for either faction spells doom for the PCs! The party must claim the Bell on their own, caught in a battle between fiends and celestials in the Astral Plane!

For Whom the Bell Tolls includes PLAYER SAFE MAPS - maps you can show your players for each encounter area that does not reveal important details like the locations of traps, treasure, or hostile creatures.

185123.description:
Ascension is a deck-building game in which players spend Runes to acquire more powerful cards for their deck. It offers a dynamic play experience where players have to react and adjust their strategy accordingly. Each player starts with a small deck of cards, and uses those cards to acquire more and better cards for their deck, with the goal of earning the most Honor Points by gaining cards and defeating monsters.

Ascension: Dreamscape is the ninth standalone game in the Ascension series, although the game can be combined with other titles for play with up to six players. This set introduces the Insight resource that allows players to acquire exclusive Dream cards. Player can also use the Dreamscape to access powerful new Vision cards as well as Heroes and Contructs.
185123.name: Ascension: Dreamscape
boardgamepodcastepisode: RDTN Episode 90: Africa – West of Africa and Ascension Dreamscape Reviews and Flying Squirrels

185124.name: Rogues (3PP)
185124.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Pathfinder Roleplaying Game offers a vast range of options for characters of all classes. This is great when a player wants to explore variations on a theme, but it comes at a cost: the character options for each class have been published across many places.

Books (hardcover compilations such as Pathfinder® Roleplaying Game Core Rulebook™ and Pathfinder® Roleplaying Game: Ultimate Combat™, plus the various companions, adventures, and chronicles);
PDFs (from Paizo and from third-party publishers);
Websites, blogs, and other online sources.




This can be intimidating to new players, and inconvenient to experienced players. The Echelon Reference Series aims to make this easier for everyone by gather information for each class into a single book.

Echelon Reference Series: Rogues collects information about the rogue and ninja classes. The base classes, archetypes for both classes, and rogue talents, advanced talents, ninja tricks, and master ninja tricks are all contained within. This book also has feats appropriate to both classes and their archetypes, and there are stat blocks for NPCs of all levels and many races.

This book contains material from the PRD and from third-party publishers.

185125.name: Rogues (PRD)
185125.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Pathfinder Roleplaying Game offers a vast range of options for characters of all classes. This is great when a player wants to explore variations on a theme, but it comes at a cost: the character options for each class have been published across many places.

Books (hardcover compilations such as Pathfinder® Roleplaying Game Core Rulebook™ and Pathfinder® Roleplaying Game: Ultimate Combat™, plus the various companions, adventures, and chronicles);
PDFs (from Paizo and from third-party publishers);
Websites, blogs, and other online sources.




This can be intimidating to new players, and inconvenient to experienced players. The Echelon Reference Series aims to make this easier for everyone by gather information for each class into a single book.

Echelon Reference Series: Rogues collects information about the rogue and ninja classes. The base classes, archetypes for both classes, and rogue talents, advanced talents, ninja tricks, and master ninja tricks are all contained within. This book also has feats appropriate to both classes and their archetypes, and there are stat blocks for NPCs of all levels and many races.

This is the PRD-Only version, containing information from the PRD.

185126.name: Javelins and Throwing Spears
185126.description:
From publisher blurb:

Call to Arms is a book line for players and gamemasters alike. Each book focuses on a different type of item, expanding rules for those items and adding everything from new mundane and magical examples of the item to new character options related to the item.

Call to Arms: Javelins and Throwing Spears includes new and varied types of magical and mundane javelins. New feats, class options, archetypes, and rules make javelins more accessible and more powerful than ever. Additional rules for javelin use in mass combat are included, putting this iconic battlefield weapon into the hands of your armies!

185127.name: Multiclass System
185127.description:
User summary:

The Multiclass System is a roleplaying game that allows characters to quickly accumulate a wide variety of abilities. Rather than utilizing a robust skill system, however, the game instead uses Classes but allows characters to engage simultaneously in multiple classes without penalty. Most of the rules are light-weight to streamline play. Most rules apply only to a single (or a few) class.

Characters begin with three Classes, each of which enables access to some class-specific Skills. Skill use, in all but trivial cases, requires a 3d6 roll below the Skill Rating. Situational modifiers may apply. Characters have a single "Stat" that functions like a universal Skill--if no Skill applies to a situation, characters roll against their "Stat".

185128.name: From Boot Hill: Horror & Adventure
185128.description:
From publisher blurb:

Death is just one of life's great experiments.
Towns occasionally go dark on the frontier. Tech fails them, bandits strike them, and sometimes they just dry up when everyone decides they don’t want to hang out in the middle of nowhere any longer. Most investigations turn up a perfectly normal explanation.

This is not one of those cases.

From Boot Hill explores this ghost town, and ghosts are the least of the adventurers' worry. Crazed wolves, zombies, mad science, and a whole township to explore: From Boot Hill is going to drive your players mad.

Includes 19 pages of adventure and exploration, suitable for hours of fun. Most adventures will last 2-3 four-hour sessions.

185129.name: Accursed Core 1
rpgseries: Cast of Cards: On-Call RPG Characters
185129.description:
From publisher blurb:

Accursed is a dark fantasy setting that requires the Savage Worlds core rules and Savage Worlds Horror Companion for use. It includes background information on the nations of Morden. Game mechanics include horrific new Witchbreeds for use as playable characters, along with Setting Rules, Hindrances, Edges, and Powers suited to telling stories set in Morden. The full setting guide also includes detailed information on eight of the Witches and their banes, as well as a range of adventure hooks and a plot point campaign.

Cast of Cards decks offer gamers ready-to-use Savage Worlds NPCs, monsters, and villains, complete with stats and background--you can just shuffle the deck, choose and play. Available for order on dry-erase marker-ready cards, or printable from the PDF you can download today, Cast of Cards decks save you time and effort.

Each deck offers 17 Extras (NPCs), including game stats and character backgrounds, as well as space to track Wounds in case you upgrade the Extra to a Wild Card.

About Cast of Cards: Accursed Core 1

Witches have ruled the land since the last battles of conquest, but their Grand Coven has been sundered, leaving behind remnants of a once-mighty army. The survivors of the horde include captured citizens of the conquered nations that fought as the Witches’ shock troops.

185130.name: Setting Works: Near-Future Rescue Worker
185130.description:
From publisher blurb:

Setting Works: Near-Future Rescue Worker continues the series of supplements designed to help you create a more immersive roleplaying experience, whether you're a player or the GM.

This supplement includes a wealth of information to help you flesh out your cyberpunk or hard sci-fi disaster stories no matter which game system you use. With a little tweaking it's even ideal for use with contemporary settings. There's a selection of futuristic equipment, a section on playing as a firefighter or medic and another for the GM to run emergency situations.

Future support for this line is going to include more elements from the near future (crime, commerce, entertainment and more), the American West, medieval castles, courts and towns, feudal Japan and more.

185131.name: Multiclass System Update
185131.description:
User summary:

This document provides updated rules to the Multiclass System. Rather than updating the whole rule document the author has provided extensive errata.

The document defines new Skills (by Class), provides rules for dual-wielding in combat, makes adjustments to the magic system, and discusses "misbehaving priests".

185132.name: Trafik
185132.description:
The purpose of Trafik is to teach primarily children age 6-14 how to travel safely through traffic.

Each player or team (of up to 2 players) gets a car that is moved around the board through dice rolls. If the player lands on a blue square he rolls again.

Other squares require the player to answer a question about traffic to proceed. The questions are divided into 3 age-appropriate difficulties: 6-12 years, 12-18 years and 18 years and above. There are 2 questions in each difficulty on each of the 90 playing cards. Which one is used is decided by whether the dice roll was even or uneven. On a correct answer you get to go again - a wrong answer ends your turn.

Finally there are squares that move you further on the board or ends your turn.

Each time a player crosses start he is awarded a traffic-sign. The first player to collect 4 wins.

rpg: FFRE: Free Fudge-light Roleplaying gaming Engine
185133.name: The Basics of FFRE
185133.description:
User summary:

The Basics of FFRE provides basic, or quick-start, access to the rule system. The Basics of FFRE actually is the final-state publication of the rules as the full set was never made publicly available in final form. Portions of the rules found here received updates or revisions in subsequent documents, notably the Enchantment Options document.

Character creation is very freeform and the rules suggest that the players, rather than the GM, should determine how many points should be placed into the initial purchase pool for abilities.

185134.name: Xoom Cubes Challenge Cards: Junior
185134.description:
From the publisher:

XOOM Cubes Word Race Games just got even faster! Inside this box you will find over 200 excited challenges! Get rolling with new word challenges from K to 3rd grade spelling lists, including Letter Races (3, 4, and 5 -letter words), Categories like “spell your favorite animal”, “favorite food” or “favorite place” and much more. Pick a card and roll the dice! XOOM Cubes is great for all ages! It’s time to get your family and friends together for lots of fun!

Are you up to the challenge?

Comes with 65 cards.

185135.name: Xoom Cubes Challenge Cards: Original
185135.description:
From the Publisher:

These cards are filled with more the 200 fun and exciting challenges in multiple categories, such as Letter Games, Category Races, Potluck, and Timed Games. Test your abilities to think fast while under pressure, spell words in record times, show off your knowledge about movies, TV, Music, Art, Geography , Science, Technology and Sports. The Categories are separated by color, making it easy to identify your favorite challenges!

rpg: FFRE: Free Fudge-light Roleplaying gaming Engine
185137.name: Familiars for FFRE
185137.description:
From the introduction:

A Familiar is an animal companion, usually intelligent, who helps the character. It may be useful as a scout or spy, in combat, as a messenger, as a mount, or, for some Familiars, all of these (at great cost)...There are several ways a character can [obtain a Familiar].

185138.name: Sample Magic Items for FFRE
rpg: FFRE: Free Fudge-light Roleplaying gaming Engine
185138.description:
User summary:

Document provides various items in these major categories: Generic Foci, Specific Foci, Weapons, Armor/Shields, Protective Items, Healing Items, Miscellaneous Items. Additionally document suggests methods for creating usable items that will fit into the game system without unbalancing play.

rpg: FFRE: Free Fudge-light Roleplaying gaming Engine
185139.name: Enchantment Options for FFRE
185139.description:
User summary:

Document provides various rules for creating permanent magic items for the game system. The system is not limited to a particular type of item, however, and extensive tables and rules are provided for various types of magic items. There are very few limitations on what characters may create.

185140.name: Jedi vs. Jedi: Blades of Light
185140.description:
UNLICENSED GAME




This game is an unlicensed version of Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith.




User Summary

Two characters fight with light sabres.

185141.name: Seguro o Ambicioso
185141.description:
This is a dice game that comes with 6 dice in a cup that can be used to throw the dice.

At the beginning of your turn you must throw all dice. Then you have to set aside at least one winning combination. If you have 350 points or more you can retire, if not you must continue with the rest of the dice. If after a throw you are unable to set aside at least one die you lose the points of the round.

There are only 10 winning combinations that let you win between 50 and 1000 points.

When a player reaches 5000 points the game will end after everyone has the same amounts of rounds.

This is a mix of several South America games like “El Ambicioso”, “Generala”, “El Juego de los Diez Mil" and “Farkle”

185142.description:
This game challenges kids and parents with more than 200 trivia questions.
Play the game to get some great advice!

Each question has a "BEEP-ed" word: the players take turns trying to find the missing word. The first player answering five correct questions wins the game.

There are special cards where players should provide an ingredient of their choice to add in a given recipe and then, the Chef in charge for that turn will choose the winner based on his own taste.

The game also features some variants as the simultaneous possibility to answer: you need to be the first to catch an item in order to get the right to answer!

The game presents four different levels of difficulty: at the beginning of the game, the players may choose to play a specific level or a mix of all four.
185142.name: Quiz Chef Junior

185143.description:
This game challenges players with more than 200 trivia questions about wine!
Play the game to get some great advice and achieve the knowledge of a sommelier!

Each question has a "BEEP-ed" word: the players take turns trying to find the missing word.
The first player answering five correct questions wins the game.

Some cards present a different challenge: simultaneous answer, or a greatest prize consisting in stealing a point from another player in addition to the normal prize for the correct answer.

The game presents four different levels of difficulty: at the beginning of the game, the players may choose to play a specific level or a mix of all four.
185143.name: Quiz Chef Vini

185144.description:
Baiting the Bear: The 1942 Soviet Kharkov Offensive, depicts the May 1942 offensive by Soviet forces under the command of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko against the German 6th Army. After initial promising signs, the offensive was stopped by German counterattacks. Critical errors by several staff officers and by Joseph Stalin, who failed to accurately estimate the 6th Army's potential and overestimated their own newly trained forces, led to a German pincer attack which cut off advancing Soviet troops from the rest of the front. The operation caused almost 300,000 Soviet casualties compared to just 20,000 for the Germans and their allies.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 1 day
Hex: 4 miles / 6.4 kilometers
Units: Battalion to Army

Game Inventory:
Two 11x17" full color map
Two dual-side printed un-mounted countersheet (260 1/2" counters)(mounted counters are optional)
One 6-page rulebook
One Player Aid Chart
Eight pages of 64 Event Cards

Player Provided: One 6-sided die

Solitaire Playability: Medium
Complexity Level: Low
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 1.5 to 2 hours
185144.name: Baiting the Bear: The 1942 Soviet Kharkov Offensive

185145.name: Ammo: Revenant War
185145.description:
User summary:

Ammo - Revenant War, also known as Ammo: The RPG, is a very simple implementation of the Fudge rules that supports a single scenario with very limited play options. In general, the characters begin in a war zone where every NPC is more-or-less trying to kill them. All aspects of the system are handled through narrative process except for firefight resolution which uses dice. Gunfire is lethal and common (in fact, constant) and thus character life expectancy is not long--the rules have no real mechanism for advancement.

185146.name: Ammo Characters
185146.description:
User summary:

Ammo Characters consists of four pre-generated characters, typically distributed as four separate, one-page PDF files. An additional one-page "build" sheet summarizes the starting equipment (e.g., guns) available to the characters. Often, an additional one-page document with a blank character sheet is bundled into a .ZIP archive.

The four characters are: The Lone Gun, The Lucky Shot, The Quickdraw, and The Twin Blitzer.

185147.description:
This Sapiens promo contains a set of 8 double-sided tiles that show each of the 8 scenes in the base game on both ends of the tile.

Setup
Before the beginning of the game, shuffle the 8 double tiles with the base tiles. Then, during setup, remove 8 tiles in addition to the normal number removed (so 20 tiles for 2 players, 26 for 3 players, and 14 for 4 players).

On Your Turn
During the game, treat double tiles just like normal tiles. Each offers the same scene twice.
185147.name: Sapiens: Double Tiles

185148.name: The Endless Well (5e)
185148.description:
From the introduction:

"The Endless Well" is a short D&D adventure for four to five 5th-level player characters (PCs). The scenario takes place in the World of Farland, specifically in the "Endless Well," a series of caverns linked through a portal to water energy in the Maelstrom (or the elemental plain of water in other D&D worlds). It is the source of a river that never dries, even in times of drought.

185149.name: The Quick and the Dead (5e)
185149.description:
From the introduction:

This is an adventure for 4 to 5 3rd level characters...The players are staying in Kenby, a small town in Kelerak. Because they have some small reputation, they will be asked by the sheriff of Kenby to investigate a disturbance plaguing the town.

185150.name: The Ties that Bind (5e)
185150.description:
From the introduction:

This is a short 5th edition D&D adventure for 4 characters of 4th level...The scenario takes place in the World of Farland, in the town of Littlespur in Kelerak, but it can be placed in any campaign; just change the names of the places to make it work with your campaign. The only real difference is the currency of Farland. Farland is on the silver standard, and as such, a silver piece is equal to a gold piece in the standard D&D campaign.

185151.name: Towers of Night (5e)
185151.description:
From the introduction:

This is an adventure for four to five 1st-level player characters...Ages ago, long before the Lord of Sloth took control of Zeland, the people of the nation were interred within great Towers of Waiting when they passed. The bodies were carried to the roofs of massive stone towers, where they lay in rest for a year's time. Here elements battered the body, removing the flesh and sending the spirits onto their next destination. After a year passed, the sun bleached bones would be cast down into the base of the tower, where a massive pit waited. This was the way of the first Zelanders, for the first 500 years. The Battleplain, where this adventure takes place, is a region dotted with many Towers of
Waiting.

185152.name: What Lurks Within (5e)
185152.description:
From the introduction:

"What Lurks Within?" is a D&D adventure for four to five 2nd-level player characters (PCs). The scenario takes place in the World of Farland, in the Kingdom of Daven, in and around a small sleepy human village named Eichen...Although the Kingdom of Daven has been plagued by evil since the Liberation, the town of Eichen was mostly spared from this suffering because of its location. Near the edge of a large forest, away from major roads and trade routes, the town has been largely unmolested. The past two months, however, have been dark times for the folk of Eichen.

185153.name: Fleur de Purge
185153.description:
User Summary

This supplement for Wastburg is centered around the Purge, the city prison. It starts with a description of the district and then the prison itself from the point of view of a guard, and then section by section.

It concludes with a long scenario of 3 different investigations in relation to the prison.

185154.description:
Wizard School is like normal school, except it's a card game where you have to carefully manage your abilities and resources to make sure that you don't flunk out of the most prosaic magical academy in all the world.

Wizard School is a cooperative card game in which 2-5 players take turns at passing tests, besting monsters in the most epic group project of all time. And yes, you are graded cumulatively. When one of you fails, you all flunk out.

Difficulty and length of games can be managed by choosing from among 20 different graduation cards, which helps ensure that each game is a new experience.

Your goal may be to graduate, but you can’t let the monsters overrun the school. As they pile up, you’re forced to use your magic just to stay alive, and you may have nothing left to pass the Graduation Milestones. If you reach an F (on the Graduation Card), it’s Game Over.
185154.name: Wizard School
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 4 - A New Hope (Gen Con Preview)
Podcast 50 – Wizard School

185156.name: Adventurer Summoning (d20)
185156.description:
From the introduction:

A mini-adventure for four 10th to 12th-level player characters...The PCs are currently in Dragonspur City or wherever they were last, doing whatever they were doing last, although they should have sufficient time to rest, memorize spells, and heal up from their last escapade. They will need their strength for what lies ahead. When they are all together, they suddenly feel a strange sensation. There is a blinding flash, vertigo strikes them, and when they regain their senses they find themselves in a strange scene...

185157.name: Dead Tree Vale (d20)
185157.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four player characters of any level...Contrary to popular rumor, the Vale is full of both plant and animal life, including many perfectly ordinary trees. However, scattered throughout the Vale, usually in clumps of two to four, but occasionally alone, stand hideous dead trees. The trees bear a passing resemblance to oak trees, save that their branches tend to be slightly fewer in number and most spread skyward rather than outward.

185158.name: The Hold of the Lich Lord (d20)
185158.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 15th to 16th level player characters...Jaef the Dark used to be the power behind the ancient throne of Kale many centuries ago. He was slain but lived on in his phylactery until he was able centuries later to find a new body and rise again, taking on the anagrammatic name of Afej the Black. He then used his vast intelligence to seize one of the towns of Kelerak and raise an orcish army to gain control of a substantial portion of the kingdom. It is the lich's goal to rule the entire kingdom, and perhaps an empire.

Enter the heroes.

185159.name: Into the Thieves' Guild (d20)
185159.description:
From the introduction:

An Adventure for Four 8th-Level Player Characters...Corfin has been the lieutenant of the Thieves’ Guild for nearly 15 years and he is sick of it. He wishes to be the head of the guild. But for some reason, all of his men are deathly afraid of the current head, one Lalsthor Longcloak. He has had no success paying anyone to assassinate Longcloak; indeed Corfin himself feels an irrational fear when he is in the mysterious presence of his leader. Therefore he has had to suffer as second in command.

185160.name: Ordeal of the Viper (d20)
185160.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 16th to 17th level player characters...The Lord of Envy has ruled Orland for many centuries. He was once a priest of Salystra, the Demon Serpent Goddess of his people, but he forsook her ways and betrayed his people long ago, turning to the worship of the Dark God Vornoth. He never took the tests that the Serpent Goddess puts all powerful drow through. Indeed, he was protected from her power by Vornoth, and through the god’s might rose to the rulership of Orland. Along the way he acquired the treacherous Chancellor Koorlsh, who learned of his weakness and seeks to exploit it to overthrow Garlgax and rule Orland in his stead. Koorlsh hopes to use the PCs as pawns in his game.

185161.name: Strange Shelter (d20)
185161.description:
From the introduction:

A mini-adventure for four 4th to 6th-level player characters...The PCs are traveling and are some distance from the nearest settlement. The only signs of civilization are the occasional frontier-style farmstead; moreover, even one of those hasn't been sighted for some hours. As the overcast, dark day is drawing to a close, suddenly a loud peal of thunder booms overhead and drops begin to sprinkle the characters. It is apparent that the sky is preparing to unleash a deluge; the cold wind will make it considerably unpleasant for the heroes to be out in it. But there seems to be no place to find shelter. Then, up ahead, the group sights what seem to be the remains of a medium-sized farmstead, made from logs. Apparently deserted, it shows the marks of a fire because only half the roof remains. All the walls are standing, though, and the place will afford surprisingly good shelter from the brewing storm.

185162.name: The Troll Pits of Hextor (d20)
185162.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 13th-level player characters...Western Zeland has it a little worse under Lord Dargon Skullcrusher. He is not slothful, and his tyranny is legendary. Dargon has had some time to fortify his fortress, the Troll Pits of Hextor, and thus the heroes should be prepared for a challenge.

185163.name: Wizard's Isle (d20)
185163.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 18th-level player characters...Millenia ago, the powerful archmage Seldorius of Farland built for himself on Hamor Island a compound and fortress where he could do his research undisturbed, and where he could found a council of wise people to combat evil in the world...

185164.name: Wyvern Attack! (d20)
185164.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 6th to 8th level player characters...the
heroes are hired by the crooked sheriff of Titan to fend off some Wyvern attacks; he suspects a villager is masterminding the attacks. In reality, the Sheriff is the mastermind, in cohorts with an evil Orcish druid, and he is trying to gain legal and actual control over an abandoned copper mine.

185165.name: Jumpman
185165.description:
User Summary

This version of Jumpman features Drake and his friends with a glittery background and simple Jumpman game play.

185166.name: The Endless Well (d20)
185166.description:
From the introduction:

A Short Adventure for Four 5th-6th Level Player Characters...Though small and relatively close to the small town Arden, the Endless Well caverns have rarely been explored, that is until recently. A few months ago several farmers, who have land that boarders on the Arden River, have been complaining that many of their livestock have been going missing. As no remains of the animals could be found, wolf and undead attacks were ruled out as a likely cause.

User summary:

The fourteen-page PDF file is distributed in a ZIP archive that also contains one overland and five dungeon maps in JPG format.

185167.name: Haunted Dwarven Tomb (d20)
185167.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four player characters of any level. A Prison in Eastern Orland, Near the Ruins of Mt. Silverload. Many years ago, dwarves from the Dwarfhold of Mithaud, or Mt. Silverload, prepared a site as a tomb for their venerable king. Prior to the king’s death, however, the crown prince and his family were brutally slain while traveling by a band of wandering Orlandish mercenaries. Groups of elite dwarven warriors were dispatched to capture or kill the murderers, and after several months one such group returned with the leader of the mercenary company as a prisoner.

User summary:

The nine-page PDF file is distributed in a ZIP archive that also contains five dungeon maps in JPG format.

185168.name: The Quick and the Dead (d20)
185168.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 3rd-level player characters...Timothy Ack-Turpin has a problem and the heroes have presented themselves as the obvious solution. After all, it isn't everyday that well-armed individuals come to Kenby, especially not people who seem to know how to use those weapons.

185169.name: The Ties that Bind (d20)
185169.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 4th to 5th level player characters...Cecil in his old age has come to realize that his acts have doomed him for eternity. He wishes to repent for his crimes, but to do this he must retrieve his holy symbol from the tomb of his brother. Cecil unfortunately can't do this in his condition and with no money he cannot hire anyone either.

185170.name: Towers of Night (d20)
185170.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 1st-level player characters...When the Lord of Sloth came to Zeland, the nobility of the Battleplain vanished. Currently, two beings view this region with interest: Beryn, a necromancer of little repute, and Drokag, a Hobgoblin with dreams of grandeur. They have come to desecrate the Towers, seeking to raise an army of undead. Their purpose is merely to gain favor in the eyes of the Lord of Sloth and his Generals. It will be up to the players to stop this little plot before it gets out of hand.

185171.name: What Lurks Within? (d20)
185171.description:
From the introduction:

An adventure for four 2nd-level player characters...Although the Kingdom of Daven has been plagued by evil since the Liberation, the town of Eichen was mostly spared from this suffering because of its location. Near the edge of a large forest, away from major roads and trade routes, the town has been largely unmolested. The past two months, however, have been dark times for the folk of Eichen.

185173.description:
From the box:

Coven: The Village adds a less abstract to your game of coven, with more flavor and storytelling. The game is set in early 16th-Century Europe, where you are a practicing witch living in a small village not too far from Innsbruck, Austria. Martin Luther has recently posted his 95 theses, setting off the firestorm of religious wars known as the Reformation. Malleus Mallificarum has been published and, although condemned by the church, is widely used in the persecution of witches.

Cover: The Village includes a new rotating Inner Wheel to replace the one from the base game. It also adds 36 Village Cards the replace the original Balance Cards, and a Village card is read when the new Inner Wheel triggers the Full Moon. Suspicion Tokens track how suspicious the villagers are of each player, and are gained whenever you increase Balance. Suspicion may also gain Personal Edict Cards, which are penalties that last for the remainder of the game, and may even prevent you from winning unless certain conditions are met. Coven: The Village also includes 36 Village Cards, 15 Personal Edict Cards, 30 Suspicion Tokens, 5 new Reference Cards, Rules, a six sided die, and an additional spindle.
185173.name: Coven: The Village

185174.name: The Still Grotto
185174.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Pathfinder compatible adventure for four characters of 3rd level.

The endless swamps and marshes of the Reedland region of the Fenian Triarchy, on the shores of the Opal Sea are a wild and fertile place, with many races living side-by-side in less than perfect harmony. Reptilian and amphibian sentient races especially like the warm waters and fecund life there, and squabble over territory, trade and religion much as their warm-blooded neighbours do, if much more, well, cold-bloodedly… The boggards and grippli of the region are a particular case, the small and peaceful grippli often preyed upon by the larger and warlike boggards, who seek more land to support their grotesquely bloated leaders. The friendly tree-frog people desperately need allies to balance the scales in the Reedlands, for they would be very useful in keeping those swamps out of renegade Elementalist hands, or the sudden rise of a boggard leader who may grow bold enough to raid human lands, like the nearby City of Boats or Kama Rue. All it would take would be to find some fragment of powerful war-magic, left over from the world-shaking NewGod Wars to push the balance of power over to one side… or the other.

185175.name: Psychics
185175.description:
From publisher blurb:

Psychic Enemies and Allies!

Occult Character Codex: Psychics contains 20 detailed psychic stat blocks for the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game, featuring every specialty from esoteric students of dream, tranqulity, and faith to masters of psychic sciences ranging from lore to psychedelia, and of course the dangerous delvers into the darkest corners of the mind that draw their power from pain, mutation, and abomination! You'll find psychic humans, halflings, elves, and dwarves, but also stranger races like nagaji, ratfolk samsarans, and sylphs, running the gamut from good to evil and all points in between. With the Occult Character Codex, you'll have an entire arsenal of psychic characters waiting and ready to blow your players' minds!

The Occult Character Codex series brings you a fantastic collection of detailed, ready-to-use stat blocks for psychic characters using the new classes in the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game Occult Adventures rulebook. These characters can be used by GMs as allies or villains, friends or rivals, helpful characters or mysterious strangers, or any other use the GM can think of. Every installment includes 20 fully developed premade characters from 1st to 20th level, drawn from many races and specialties within each class and designed with a full array of spells, magic items, feats, psychic abilities, and detailed tactics for ease of use. If you'd love to introduce elements of the new psychic and occult rules into your campaign but feel a bit overwhelmed by the sheer volume of new material to absorb, this is the book for you. Each Occult Character Codex is an ideal complement to the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game NPC Codex from Paizo, Inc.

185176.name: Tribes of Everglow
185176.description:
From publisher blurb:

A detailed look into the minds and societies of all the varied pony tribes of Everglow. See how they view each other and the other races of the world, how they handle birth, life, and death, and their unique perspectives shown in contrast with one another.

Over a hundred new feats
Class Archetypes
Dozens of Alchemy Discoveries
Rogue tricks
Prestige class
New equipment
New spells
New Lore and history
A whole new tribe, the short legs.

185177.name: A Night at the Museum
185177.description:
From publisher blurb:

Violence, murder, and a lingering paranormal presence bring Corktown Precinct investigators to the Detroit Institute of Art. Two guards are dead, priceless artifacts are smashed, and a 2,000 year old mummy is missing. Or is it?

A Night at the Museum is a sample 1-sheet adventure for The Thin Blue Line - A Detroit Police Story. The adventure is packaged with six pre-generated Corktown Officers, all ready to be used as starting player characters.

The Thin Blue Line is a modern horror setting that requires the Savage Worlds Core Rulebook and the Savage Worlds Horror Companion for use. The characters included with this adventure do reference abilities specific to the setting book, but the 1-sheet could be played with only the Core Rulebook, if the game group wished to create their own characters.

185178.name: FFRPS: Free Fantasy Role Playing System
rpg: FFRPS: Free Fantasy Role Playing System
185178.description:
User summary:

FFRPS, the Free Fantasy Role Playing System, was developed with several design goals in mind. Primarily, it was free, with rules that attempted to be intuitively simple. A secondary goal to enable "paperless" play (via software) was not particularly successful. The game is interesting inasmuch as it was intended only as a partial replacement for TSR's Advanced Dungeons & Dragons. Major portions of FFRPS used the AD&D ruleset without modification. Other portions of FFRPS were completely new material. It can thus be viewed as either a large-scale "variant" rule set for AD&D or as an independent game that borrows heavily from AD&D. Either interpretation is correct, depending upon focus. An add-on component of science and technology was contemplated but not produced.

The major ways in which FFRPS was innovative surrounded character and NPC creation and the implementation of magic within a campaign. It is safe to say that in nearly all other respects it was a near-clone of AD&D. Characters in FFRPS were required to be human. They had two types of Characteristics--Primaries and Secondaries. Six Primaries were defined: Strength, Intelligence, Faith, Dexterity, Constitution, and Charisma--usually ranging from -2 to +2. Primary ranks were purchased from a point pool. Three Secondaries were defined: Mana, To Hit Armor Class 0 ("THAC0"), and Hit Points. Secondary ranks were derived values. Characters' proficiency was noted in several "levels": Adventuring Level, Combat Level, Magic Level, and Piety Level. Secondary Skills were deleted in favor of a narrative character background.

Magic was reworked to use a mana point system, with spells placed in schools. Some spell parameters (range, duration, area-of-effect) could be varied at casting time. Spell Levels were somewhat dynamic based upon desired outcomes. However, every spell cast had a potential of failure, determine using a complex formula. Spell targets were allowed saving throws using a complex formula.

185179.name: Q.U.B.E: Director's Cut
185179.description:
Q.U.B.E: Director’s Cut is the definitive version of the brain-twisting first-person puzzler. Using special high-tech gloves to manipulate cubes in the environment, the player solves an array of conundrums – from physics-based challenges; to 3D jigsaws; to platform-based trials. This time the mind bending gameplay will be accompanied by a completely new story by award-winning writer Rob Yescombe with voice acting from the likes of Rachel Robinson (Fang in Final Fantasy XIII) and Rupert Evans (As seen in Ridley Scott’s TV drama, World Without End). The game also has an all-new original soundtrack and a special time trial mode with 10 levels, called Against the Qlock.

Source: The Game Website.

185180.name: Droits dans Leurs Bottes
185180.description:
User Summary:

A Wastburg supplement.

People get slapped for no reason. 2 scenarios for the PCs to investigate these strange happenings.

185181.name: L'Opéra de Quat'gelders
185181.description:
User Summary:

A Wastburg supplement.

Two scenarios involving smart criminals, not the kind the guards often encounter, scenarios that can be played independently or in one continuous story.

185182.name: Dieux Ennemis
185182.description:
User Summary

This is the French edition of Enemy Gods, enhanced by extra material as well as rule changes.

(Translated & abridged) Publisher's blurb

Incarnate a hero dedicated to a powerful pantheon, as well as one of these gods in the World, the sword & sorcery universe of Enemy Gods !
If you are a god, you need a hero to advance your cause with the mortals. Most players will take a hero and a god that get along very well, but more audacious players will go as far as to make hero and gods mortal enemies.

185183.name: Taxi Challenge New York
185183.description: Taxi Challenge! Who is the fastest cab driver and who gets $100 first during a work shift. Face difference challenges during your shift and you may get a big reward for a job well done. Its own excitement to the game comes with occurrence cards and tactical cards. Roll a die and move your pawn to nearest taxi bollard to find your next customer.

185184.name: Le Musée de Lhomme
185184.description:
(Translated) Publisher Blurb

Le Musée de Lhomme is a compilation of players aid and 20 scenarios written by one of the most generous advocate for Call of Cthulhu (in France): Tristan Lhomme. Most of them already published, all have been rewritten to allow newbies to play them more easily and the veterans to rediscover them.

This boxed set contains 7 booklets:

• À la découverte du Musée de Lhomme, helps you pick tonight secenarion.
• Abominations & désolations, regroup several players aide to be used in any situation.
• Horreurs du Nouveau Continent, regroup eleven scenarios in the USA in the 20s.
• Horreurs du Vieux Continent, offer 5 scenarios in Europa in the 20s.
• La Débâcle, presents two scenarios and a players aide to play in France in the 40s.
• Le 7e Chant de Maldoror, is a long scenario in the US in the 60s.
• La saga Félicie, explore Cambodia in the 70s and the organization Félicie.
Two appendix complete these booklets and make an essemble of stories selected carefully in a prestigious edition.

Le Musée de Lhomme is a French creation and the richest compendinum ever published for the RPG Call of Cthulhu. The author demonstrate once again his talent of story teller that inspired hundreds of keepers and terrified thousands of investigators.

185185.description:
After countless battles, the King and Queen have grown worried of the strength of their army and thus have issued a decree for their soldiers to train more! Together, a Rook and Bishop practice their combat skills in Red Rook Blue Bishop.

Red Rook Blue Bishop is a micro abstract game that can fit 1 or more players, though 1-4P is recommended as the board is relatively small. The components are minimal, the gameplay is simple, and players may jump in and out at their leisure.

The gameplay takes inspiration from both Ricochet Robots and the movements of a Rook and Bishop in Chess. The goal is to be the first player to reach 3 points, and a point is rewarded every time a player successfully points out a path to the target.
185185.name: Red Rook Blue Bishop

185186.name: Battle for Kirovograd
185186.description:
Battle for Kirovograd is a simulation of the battles in January 1944 between the German 8th Army and the Soviet 2nd Ukrainian Front. The battle took place in freezing, often blizzard conditions, around the city of Kirovograd. While the Soviets were able to capture the city, both sides fought themselves to a standstill with extremely high losses due to combat and extreme weather.

Each turn of Battle for Kirovograd equals 1 day. One hex equals 2 miles. Unit counters represent battalions, regiments, brigades and divisions. The game lasts for 12 Turns.

185187.description:
You and your fellow fishermen are having a whale of a time on the high seas. The fish are literally jumping into your boats. So many fish are landing on deck that your boats are beginning to overload and capsize. The only way to tackle this fishy situation is to release all of the fish you've caught before you take a trip to Davy Jones' locker. The winner is the first fisherman to release all of their fish. Good luck and let cod be with you!

Each turn in No Fish!, players guess a number or special fish type. If they guess correctly, they release all of those fish from their hand and may take a special action; if they guess incorrectly, the other players call "No Fish!" and that player has to draw a card from the fish deck. The special action fish — Starfish, Toadfish, Flyingfish, Lionfish and Monkfish — are what separates this game from a generic number-guessing game to a game of strategy, bluffing and manipulation.

Each pack contains 54 cards: four types of basic fish (Goldfish, Dogfish, Rainbowfish and Clownfish) numbered 1-10, five types of special fish (Starfish, Toadfish, Flyingfish, Lionfish (three copies of each) and Monkfish (two copies)).
185187.name: No Fish!

185194.name: Jomsborg
185194.description:
Jomsborg is freely based on an ancient viking game.

The game board is made to symbolise the viking stronghold Jomsborg and the game is centred around the struggle between Harald Bluetooth (Harald Blåtand) and his son Sweyn Forkbeard (Svend Tveskæg). The player playing Sweyn starts at the center of the board with 1 king and 28 vikings. Harald starts as an outer rim on the board with 1 king and 47 vikings.

The players take turn moving one piece at a time. Pieces are moved horizontally or vertically - never diagonally - on the board. Vikings can move as many or few spaces as they want in one direction without crossing other pieces. Kings can only move one space at a time.

Kings can only be beaten by a king moving to the same space. Vikings can be beaten by having enemy pieces on 2 opposite sides of it. Beaten pieces are removed from play. A piece is captured if it is surrounded by pieces on all 4 sides and at least one of these are an enemy piece.

Sweyn wins by having his king reach the outer rim of the board or by capturing or beating Harald. Harald wins by capturing Sweyn or by beating him.

185195.name: Urbis
185195.description:
You’ve been given a unique opportunity to become a head of the magnificent city of Urbis. There is always a plenty of those who are eager to take this place, so when such a chance comes up, they’re ready to take it by all means.

The city of Urbis is ruled by the City Council elected by the residents. The main objective of the game is to become the Head of the Council. Like all the other players, you are a Council member who is responsible for the well-being and prosperity of the city. Each Council member (player) has an access to the city treasury and guard, and is obliged to follow the Council’s decreets. Each councillor is in charge of one of the city blocks (represented by a board given to each player in the beginning of the game) and aspires to develop his block either quickly or proficiently. Gold and silver from the treasury are distributed depending on the buildings that have been put up on the block. However the block residents are always on the lookout: no one wants to live close to the cemetery, gibbet or prison. Take thought for the residents, spend some money, and these grim buildings will appear on the neighbour’s block instead of your own. Hospital is also an essential city institution but it demands substantial charges to maintain. Taking this into account a player might awaken his inner dictator and build up his block with slums and honky-tonks, regardless of the residents’ needs, because the first player to fill all the building slots on his block becomes a winner. Which way is the best? To consider the block residents or to just execute the will of the Council? To turn your block into a dark place or a blooming garden? In Urbis you’ll have to make decisions promptly.

185196.description:
Find the lost runes and save the planet Asteros!

A long, long time ago, the ancient King of Asteros confined the brutal monsters in the Rune Gate and sealed it with four divine runes. But five days ago, a mysterious evil power opened the gate and changed the code. Asteros is haunted by fear and disasters again! The wise leader ORAKL asked the Council of United Planets and they sent four famous agents: EKHO, HAL, ELLI and NOVA. ORAKL the wise and the four brave agents begin to fight against the evil powers to save Asteros. They must find the Code to reset the Gate and confine the monsters again. People call them "Rising 5", hoping they will be able to restore peace on the planet.

Rising 5: Runes of Asteros is a co-operative deduction and adventure game with a mobile phone application or a game master. Players must find the answer Code with the four Runes in the right arrangement before the evil power devours the planet. Players can explore the planet to collect energy or clues and to fight against evil monsters. When players try to unlock the code, the App or the game master will give signs that lead to right code.

If players successfully find the code, they win; if the Darkness Level reaches the Red Moon because of the evil monsters or if the Character card deck is exhausted, the players lose the game.
185196.name: Rising 5: Runes of Asteros
boardgamepodcastepisode: Cult of the New Board Game Podcast Episode 025 – Gen Con 2016
Cult of the New Board Game Podcast Episode 030a – New Releases, News, Kickstarters
Episode #34 – Rising 5
HLG 10: Meer Essen

185197.description:
This map is an unofficial Fan made expansion. Symbols & Graphics Copyright © 2004-2015 Days of Wonder, Inc. Produced with permission of Days of Wonder, for non-commercial use only.


This follows the principles of the basic Ticket to Ride game on a special board with special cards and rules. The object of the game is to gain the most points by travelling various routes and outwitting other players. You will need the train pieces and the train cards from either the US or Europe base games (or you can buy them from the Days of Wonder shop. You can use stations if you wish.

There is an extra set of cards for the "cities", each with a value to be earned by visiting that "city". These cards are dealt/picked up alongwith tickets in the same quantity and with the same 'keep/dispose' rules. Some of the cards give you extra facilities to complete your tickets. There are also up to 9 bonuses for the end-of-game scoring.

The board does not have any grey tracks or parallel tracks, though there are limited selective options for these.

The main new rule is the option to discard 5 cards and pick up 5 new ones, as your turn. This is very useful if you are desperate for engines or a particular colour card. You can also call time when your wagon stock reaches 3, if you want, giving you the advantage of stopping other players completing tickets.
185197.name: Alaska (fan expansion to Ticket to Ride)

You will need the train pieces and the train cards from either the US or Europe base games (or you can buy them from the Days of Wonder shop. You can use stations if you wish.

There is an extra set of cards for the "cities", each with a value to be earned by visiting that "city". These cards are dealt/picked up alongwith tickets in the same quantity and with the same 'keep/dispose' rules. Some of the cards give you extra facilities to complete your tickets. There are also up to 9 bonuses for the end-of-game scoring.

The board does not have any grey tracks or parallel tracks, though there are limited selective options for these.

The main new rule is the option to discard 5 cards and pick up 5 new ones, as your turn. This is very useful if you are desperate for engines or a particular colour card. You can also call time when your wagon stock reaches 3, if you want, giving you the advantage of stopping other players completing tickets.
185215.name: Slovakia (fan expansion to Ticket to Ride)

185216.description:
This map is an unofficial Fan made expansion. Symbols & Graphics Copyright © 2004-2015 Days of Wonder, Inc. Produced with permission of Days of Wonder, for non-commercial use only.

The object of the game is to gain the most points by travelling various routes and outwitting other players. You will need the train pieces and the train cards from either the US or Europe base games (or you can buy them from the Days of Wonder shop. You can use stations if you wish.

There is an extra set of cards for the "cities", each with a value to be earned by visiting that "city". These cards are dealt/picked up alongwith tickets in the same quantity and with the same 'keep/dispose' rules. Some of the cards give you extra facilities to complete your tickets. 185217.description:

185218.description:
This map is an unofficial Fan made expansion. Symbols & Graphics Copyright © 2004-2015 Days of Wonder, Inc. Produced with permission of Days of Wonder, for non-commercial use only.


This follows the principles of the basic Ticket to Ride game on a special board with special cards and rules. The object of the game is to gain the most points by travelling various routes and outwitting other players. You will need the train pieces and the train cards from either the US or Europe base games (or you can buy them from the Days of Wonder shop. You can use stations if you wish.

There is an extra set of cards for the "cities", each with a value to be earned by visiting that "city". These cards are dealt/picked up alongwith tickets in the same quantity and with the same 'keep/dispose' rules. Some of the cards give you extra facilities to complete your tickets. There are also up to 9 bonuses for the end-of-game scoring.

The board does not have any grey tracks or parallel tracks, though there are limited selective options for these.

The main new rule is the option to discard 5 cards and pick up 5 new ones, as your turn. This is very useful if you are desperate for engines or a particular colour card. You can also call time when your wagon stock reaches 3, if you want, giving you the advantage of stopping other players completing tickets.
185218.name: Western Isles (fan expansion to Ticket to Ride)

185219.name: Investor
185219.description:
Investor is a game about owning and investing in companies. Each player starts of with a private fortune, a company and a company fortune.

The turn order is decided by the company you start with and every time you pass start you will be able to buy more companies - and thereby get more turns each round. Passing start also adds more money to your fortune and allows you to pay out dividend from your company if you have qualified.

Movement is decided by rolling either one or two dice - the player decides - but if you roll 2 and get two of the same you will receive a bonus. Where you land you will have to pay rent but that will also allow you to place your company logo on the square. From then on all players that land on the square will have to pay you rent as well.

If you get your logo on 5 different types of squares or a lot of players land on the same squares this makes the companies on them worth more.

In the game you can pay to get helpers in the form of lawyers and accountants that makes it possible to buy and sell more companies and negate consequences of special squares and event cards such as tax and a visit from the Fraud Squad.

Before the game starts it is decided when to end the game: At a certain time, at a certain fortune, at a certain number of companies owned or so on. The game should have a length of minimum an hour though. When the game ends your fortune is tallied up and the one with the largest one wins.

185220.name: Miasma
185220.description:
From the Introduction:


Mamoru circled the Oni, keeping his shield up to deflect the savage blows of the demon's large club. This shield wasn't blocking all of the damage, though: he felt himself get shaken with every hit. Worse yet, his strength was slowly leaking away: keeping the heavy shield up took much of his energy. He needed an opening soon...



Then, the demon clutched its club above its head with both hands, ready to land a devastating blow. That was the chance Mamoru had been waiting for! With the demon gearing up for the attack, its right side was open. He rolled to the right and struck the Oni's exposed flank as its club smashed into the crumbling pavement where Mamoru had stood only moments before.



It was not enough. Unexpectedly, the demon followed up with a wide sweep of its club, catching Mamoru's unshielded left side. Mamoru felt his strength leave his body, the dark power of the Miasma flowing over and out of him.



Minutes later, he opened his eyes again. He was back at the base camp, his captain prodding him with the back-end of his lance. "You died there, boy. All of us did. Got too greedy. Get up, we're going to try again to slay that Oni. Let's hope our power is still there when we get back to its lair."


Miasma is a game where you play a samurai, infected by a dark miasma that has held the Imperial Capital in its grip for centuries. In this game, you will wage desperate battles against the monsters that appeared in the wake of the miasma. To stop the monsters from overtaking all of the land, you will become a monster yourself, and commit your body and soul to the fight.

185221.name: Lost & Found
185221.description: Lost something? No worries! In Lost'n'Found you have to be quick and careful: memorize the images, flip the card, then name the item that was lost but now appeared before your opponent does it. Be the first one to name five "found" items to win the game. Thanks to the various difficulty levels, parents and kids will both find Lost'n'Found engaging.

185222.name: The Minion Recipes
185222.description:
The Annual Alchemy Competition is taking place today! Gather the ingredient elements within the time limit, throw them into a magical pot, and create the minions written in the recipes. The one who has created many and powerful minions wins the competition!

The Minion Recipes takes place over five rounds, and in each round players draft both element cards and pot cards. When a player has a pot and the necessary elements to complete one of the recipes on display, they can stop the round in order to create the minion, possibly taking advantage of its special ability at the same time. Players can drop out of the round in the middle of a draft, throwing away the remaining cards instead of passing them, but they forfeit the ability to create a minion. Players can carry over three cards into the next round, giving them a head start toward a recipe, but everyone can see which recipes are available, so you'll still be racing to complete something before anyone else.

185223.description:
This is a game played with 18 cards: each with a different value.

You play with only 2 cards at a time in your hand and manipulate other players to gather the best cards for yourself.

The object is to gain the most points.
185223.name: The Wizard of Wookey Hole

185224.name: Nouveaux Contes de la Vallée du Miskatonic
rpgissuearticle: Nouveaux contes de la vallée du Miskatonic
185224.description:
User Summary

This is the French version of New Tales of the Miskatonic Valley. It includes new art and has a few paragraphs removed in the introduction.

This supplement for Call of Cthulhu includes 6 scenarios in the mythic lands of H P Lovecraft: Arkham, Dunwich and Kingsport in the 20s.

- The Reeling Midnight
- Wasted Youth
- Spirit of Industry
- Proof of Life
- Malice Everlasting
- The Night War

185225.name: Quiz Granny o Cywilizacji: część 1
185225.description:
In Quiz Granny o Cywilizacji: część 1 (Granna's Quiz about Civilization: part 1) players move on the board with 18 fields arranged into circle and try correctly answer question from card.

Player rolls dice and move. If move ends on field with other player's pawn, he try answer question and if it's correct he gains point. Player with 3 points is the winner.

185226.name: Woe
185226.description:
Terror and plague reign in the great kingdoms of the East. You are a ruler of one of the great City-States and you must war against the other kings to secure resources and ensure the survival of your kingdom.
Woe is a drafting card game for 2-5 players where your goal is to gather resources and deprive your opponents in order to become the strongest kingdom. The first player to accumulate 5 of two of the resource types wins.

Players draft a hand a 5 cards and then play the hand, attempting to get singles, pairs, triples, etc. Resource cards in-hand will typically gain you 1 resource per card. Warrior and Priest cards allow you to manipulate the resources and cards of other players.

Once a hand is complete then a new hand is dealt, drafted and played. This happens until one player has 5 of two different resources.

185227.name: Le Manuel des Investigateurs
185227.description:
User Summary

Le Manuel des Investigateurs is the French version of the 1920s Investigator's Companion for Call of Cthulhy. It contains content from both volumes put together (and translated) into one book. A resource for any player who want to create an investigator in the 20s

185228.name: ROLF!
185228.description:
ROLF! is a stunningly simple party game that includes a plethora of phrase cards. On the back of each card are two unfinished phrases. On the front of each card is the word that finishes the phrases, and the first letter of this word.

For example:

The back of a card could have the phrase,

"Everybody was Kung-Fu ______"

And the front of the card would show:

F
Fighting

On a player's turn, they will read the phrase and then hold the card up so that all players can see the correct word that finishes the phrase.

Players must finish the phrase out loud with a word that begins with the same letter, but NOT the correct word.

So we could end up with:

"Everybody was Kung-Fu fantastic"
"Everybody was Kung-Fu farming""
"Everybody was Kung-Fu flamboyant"
"Everybody was Kung-Fu fracking"
"Everybody was Kung-Fu farting"

The judge then picks their favorite, and the winning player gets the card and a point. The winning player of the round then becomes the judge for the next round.

185229.name: Totta vai Tarua?
185229.description:
Trivia game with 1000 unexpected, funny and surprising questions.
Be fastest some times only one can answer. Speak Finnish, ask questions, tell the scores and comment about game-play. Includes 3 AA battery.

185230.name: Gryphon Knight Epic
185230.description:
It tells the story of Sir Oliver and Áquila, an accomplished knight and his loyal gryphon that are forced back to adventure once again.

Sir Oliver have already defeated a dragon, married a princess and saved the kingdom. But during his quest he will face adversaries he never imagined he would, because… in reality all of them were once friends. What happened? These heroes would never go rogue… and all at once? Something is rotten in the kingdom and its up to Oliver discover what.

Source: The Developer Website.

185232.name: Gothic Earth Eternal
185232.description:
From the introduction:

Gothic Earth Eternal is a netbook project by Rucht Lilavivat and the Fraternity of Shadows. It is a Pathfinder 2012 update of Gothic Earth. What you hold before you represents the culmination of a year-long project. It is a continuation of the setting that was started in 1994 by William W. Connors and TSR. It was written and reviewed to some degree, though it does not bear the strong foundations of a work rigorously tested. That, we leave to you. We hope you enjoy what we have worked on. We hope that you use our material to craft your own games, your own stories, and your own worlds. And if you do, tell us about them!

May all of your horror games end with a fright in your heart, a chill in your stomach and a prickling on your skin.

Good scares to all!

185233.name: Survey on the Zherisian Expedition
185233.description:
The Fraternity of Shadows Presents
Survey on the Zherisian Expedition
A Ravenloft Community Netbook

User summary:

A campaign setting developed as a (fictional) comprehensive geographical society report of an expedition into unknown lands, dated 20 February 760. Well-developed with high production quality. Includes Paridon (Geographical Survey, Sociological Survey, Religious Survey) and Timor (Geographical Survey, Sociological Survey). With Appendices to support game play, especially suitable for Dungeon Master use.

185234.name: Survey on the Expedition to the Nocturnal Sea
185234.description:
The Fraternity of Shadows Presents
Survey on the Expedition to the Nocturnal Sea
A Ravenloft Community Netbook

User summary:

A campaign setting developed as a (fictional) comprehensive geographical society report of an expedition across unknown sea expanses and onto discovered islands therein, dated 20 July 760. Well-developed with high production quality. Includes the islands of Liffe, Vecher, l'Île de la Tempête, Isle of Ravens, Graben, and Todstein. With Appendices to support game play, especially suitable for Dungeon Master use.

185235.name: Tisch-Fußballspiel
185235.description: This is a soccer game. The player who scores the most goals in a prearranged time wins the game. Each team has 11 player figures. Movement is one space per turn for an attacking player figure and any spaces in a straight line along friendly player figures or empty spaces for the ball. The defender may move one player figure two spaces or two player figures one space.

185236.name: Survey on the Souragne Expedition
185236.description:
The Fraternity of Shadows Presents
Survey on the Souragne Expedition
A Ravenloft Community Netbook

User summary:

A campaign setting developed as a (fictional) comprehensive geographical society report of an expedition into unknown lands, dated 29 October 759. Well-developed with high production quality. Includes a Geographical Survey, a Sociological Survey, and a Religious Survey. With Appendices to support game play, especially suitable for Dungeon Master use.

In some references this product is referred to as "The Souragne Gazetteer".

185237.name: Survey on the Souragne Expedition Web Enhancement
185237.description:
Survey on the Souragne Expedition
Some Precisions and New Material
Web Enhancement

User summary:

Web-enhancement document to supplement the Survey on the Souragne Expedition. Includes additional sociological information to supplement the released materials. Includes several random tables, etc. Especially suitable for Dungeon Master use.

185238.name: La Demeure de R'lyeh
185238.description:
User Summary

This is the French edition of The House of R'lyeh, 5 scenarios for Call of Cthulhu classic 20's time period.

The French edition differ from the original in the art and layout.

185239.name: Robinson: The Journey
videogamehonor: 2016 Gamescom Best Virtual Reality Game of the Year Nominee
185239.description:
Go beyond boundaries in Robinson: The Journey, a brand new virtual reality game from Crytek. Harnessing the power of CRYENGINE, Robinson: The Journey will offer players an unparalleled sense of presence in a game world as they assume the role of a young boy who has crash-landed on a mysterious planet. With freedom to explore their surroundings in 360 degrees of detail, players will become pioneers by interacting with the rich ecosystem around them and unearthing incredible secrets at every turn.

Source: The Developer Website.

185240.name: Nickel & Dime: Robin Hood's Band of Outlaws
185240.description:
Author's Description:

Nickel & Dime is the RPG to play when you are asked, "What's a roleplaying game?"

Roleplayers are sometimes asked about their hobby. Not every day, but it happens often enough that it’s handy to be able to give a five-minute demonstration that will hopefully pique the inquirer's interest for more.

Nickel & Dime is just that: a demo game that’s a tiny example (just two pages!) of a traditional RPG. It includes two five-minute encounters: run one, it's a nickel. Run them both, it's a dime!

To play, you need two coins of different values. In these rules, the lesser value coin is called a nickel (5¢) and the greater a dime (10¢), but any two values will do.

Nickel & Dime: Robin Hood's Band of Outlaws is the first in a series of different genres. The more well-known a genre, the easier it is for a new player to "get into character."
